questions.question: In physics, work is defined as:
options: Any physical or mental activity that requires effort.
The product of force and the time over which it is applied.
The transfer of energy by a force acting over a displacement.
The rate at which energy is used.
questions.explanation: Work is the transfer of energy via a force acting through a displacement.

questions.question: Work is a __________ quantity, and its SI unit is the __________.
questions.explanation: Work is a scalar measured in Joules (J).

questions.question: If a person holds a 50 kg box stationary at shoulder height for 10 minutes, how much work is done on the box? (Use $g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: No displacement means no work: $W = Fd\cos\theta = 0$ J.

questions.question: When the force applied to an object is perpendicular ($90^{\circ}$) to its displacement, the work done by that force is:
Which of the following is an example of zero work being done by a force?
options: A person pushing a car that starts to move.
Centripetal force acting on a satellite in a circular orbit.
A weightlifter dropping a barbell to the floor.
An apple falling from a tree.
questions.explanation: Centripetal force is perpendicular to displacement, so $W = 0$.

questions.question: If the angle $\theta$ between the force and displacement vectors is $180^{\circ}$, the work done is:
Positive work is done on an object when:
options: The force has a component in the direction of the displacement.
The force is perpendicular to the displacement.
The object moves at a constant velocity with no forces acting on it.
The force is removed from the object.

questions.question: Net work ($W_{net}$) is calculated by:
options: Taking the vector sum of all forces and multiplying by time.
Adding the work done by each individual force algebraically.
Always subtracting friction from the applied force work.
Multiplying the total mass by the total distance.
questions.explanation: Work is scalar, so net work = algebraic sum of work by each force.

questions.question: One Joule (J) is mathematically equivalent to:
The mathematical definition of work for a constant force is:
questions.explanation: The general formula for work by a constant force is $W = Fd\cos\theta$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the fundamentals of work.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the conditions for positive, negative, and zero work.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on $W = Fd\cos\theta$ and when work is zero.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study the definition of work and how it depends on angle.
